bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Adrian Macia, October 21, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] appreciates Macia's willingness to donate Building No. 1 and a small plot of land to memorialize the Commission.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Adrian Macia, October 21, 1940
div1.opener:
October 21, 1940
Senor Adrian Macia
Manzana de Gomez No. 325
Habana, Cuba
My dear Senor Macia:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how greatly I appreciate your wonderful generosity
in expressing your willingness to present to me as the representative of a small
memorial committee, the remains of the historical wooden building on the San Jose
farm where Major Walter Reed and his colleagues so ably proved the concept of
Finlay. The story of the work of Finlay, ihis assistant, Delgado, and that of
the United States Army Yellow Fever Commission, has always thrilled me, and I
deem it a great privilege to have had a part in discovering, in this building,
one of the few remaining symbols of their achievement. It is my hope that,
among friends, I can raise at least a small sum of money to restore this little
building and memorialize it, either on its present site, or perhaps, better yet,
to have it removed to the grounds of the Military Hospital where the Cuban govern-
ment plans to build a larger memorial. It will be wonderfully suitable to have
this small building housed in a proper shrine and cared for for years to come.
I believe also that the actual site where this building and the other small build-
ings were should be memorialized in some way, and think the suggestion of Senor
Pogolotti an excellent one; namely, ornamental concrete pillars connected with
iron ornamental chains and in the center of the plot, perhaps a granite boulder
with an appropriate bronze marker. Just how much these ventures will cost I do
not yet know, but I shall do my best to raise the necessary funds among American
friends, and present these memorials to the Cuban government. Let me assure you
I have no ulterior motive whatever, but merely the effort to glorify those who
contributed to the conquest of yellow fever.

Your own contribution in presenting the small building and a small plot
of ground on that site to me for this purpose is a wonderful beginning to this
venture. I shall be proud, indeed, to be the owner for a short time, in name
only, of this historical spot. I have not had the privilege of hearing from you
directly. If the above is truly your wish, I would be most grateful if you would
send me an airmail special delivery with a brief message to that effect, using the
enclosed envelope to reach me at the time of the dedication exercises, that I may
announce your generous action on that occasion.

closer.salute: Believe me, most sincerely and gratefully yours,
